'''Xiao-Li Meng''' ({{zh|c=孟晓犁}}) (born 1963) is an award-winning [[Chinese American]] [[statistician]], and the Whipple V. N. Jones Professor of [[Statistics]] at [[Harvard University]]. He received the [[COPSS Presidents' Award]] in 2001.<ref>"Committee of Presidents of Statistical Societies: Presidents' Award: Past Award Recipients," National Institute of Statistical Sciences, accessed June 5, 2011, [http://nisla05.niss.org/copss/PastAwardsPresidents.pdf http://nisla05.niss.org/copss/PastAwardsPresidents.pdf].</ref> He has written numerous research papers about [[Markov chain Monte Carlo]] algorithms and other statistical methodology. 

Since 2004 Meng has been Chair of Harvard's Department of Statistics, where he has helped create innovative new statistics courses designed to give students a more positive impression of the subject.<ref>Lock, Kari and Xiao-Li Meng. "[http://www.stat.harvard.edu/Courses/LockMengICOTS.pdf Real-Life Module Statistics: A Happy Harvard  Experiment]." International Conference on Teaching Statistics, Ljubljana, Slovenia, July 11–16, 2010, .</ref> He edited the journals ''Bayesian Analysis'' from 2003 to 2005 and ''Statistica Sinica'' from 2005 to 2008.<ref>"Abbreviated Curriculum Vitae of Xiao-Li Meng," Department of Statistics, Harvard University, accessed June 5, 2011, [http://www.stat.harvard.edu/Faculty_Content/Meng-cv.pdf http://www.stat.harvard.edu/Faculty_Content/Meng-cv.pdf].</ref> On August 14, 2012, Xiao-Li Meng was appointed dean of [[Harvard Graduate School of Arts and Sciences]] (GSAS).<ref>{{cite web|title=Xiao-Li Meng Appointed Dean of Harvard’s Graduate School|url=http://harvardmagazine.com/2012/08/xiao-li-meng-dean-harvard-graduate-school-arts-and-sciences|publisher=Harvard Magazine|accessdate=17 January 2013}}</ref> 

Meng received his B.Sc. from [[Fudan University]] in 1982 and his Ph.D. in statistics from [[Harvard University]] in 1990. He was elected a fellow of the [[Institute of Mathematical Statistics]] in 1997<ref>"IMS Fellows," Institute of Mathematical Statistics, accessed June 5, 2011, [http://www.imstat.org/awards/honored_fellows.htm http://www.imstat.org/awards/honored_fellows.htm].</ref> and of the [[American Statistical Association]] in 2004.<ref>"ASA Fellows," American Statistical Association, accessed June 5, 2011, [http://www.amstat.org/careers/fellowslist.cfm http://www.amstat.org/careers/fellowslist.cfm].</ref>
